titleStmt.title: Mercurius publicus: comprising the sum of forraign intelligence ...[no.29 (12 July-19 July 1660)]
Mercurius publicus (London, England : 1659)

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 37 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 9 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

availability.p: This keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above is co-owned by the institutions providing financial support to the Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership. This Phase I text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal. The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

titleStmt.title: Mercurius publicus: comprising the sum of forraign intelligence ...[no.29 (12 July-19 July 1660)]
Mercurius publicus (London, England : 1659)
titleStmt.author: Muddiman, Henry, fl.1659-1666, editor.
Dury, Giles editor.
Newcomb, Thomas, d. 1681 or 2, publisher.

biblFull.extent: v. Began with numb. 1 (29 Dec. 1659-5 Jan. 1660); ceased with numb. 33 (13-20 Aug. 1663).

notesStmt.note: Subtitle varies: 1660, "... comprising the sum of forraign intelligence"; 1661-1663, "... comprising the sum of all affairs now in agitation."
By Henry Muddiman and Giles Dury. Cf. Nelson and Seccombe.
Printed variously by: John Macock, Thomas Newcomb, Richard Hodgkinson, D. Maxwell, Peter Lillicrap, James Cottrell.
Numb. 43 (18-25 Oct. 1660) is a second copy of The Parliamentary intelligencer for those dates, mistakenly titled Mercurius publicus.
Thomason collection does not have complete run.
Reels listed in chronological order of serial publication; holdings dispersed throughout collection.
Reproduction of the originals in the British Library.
Enumeration begins again at numb. 1 annually.
No issue numbered 52 in 1660, no issue numbered 44 in 1661; chronology is continuous.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: Numb. 29. Mercurius Publicus: COMPRISING The Sum of Forraign Intelligence; WITH The Affairs now in Agitation in England, Scotland, and Ireland. For Information of the People. Publi≈øhed by Order. From Thur≈øday July 12. to Thur≈øday July 19. 1660.
Thur≈øday Iuly 12.
div.p: THis day dyed that eminent Servant of his Maje≈øtie, Iohn Lord Culpepper Ma≈øter of the Rolles, and one of his Maje≈øties mo≈øt Honourable Privy Council, who≈øe incomparable Abilities and readine≈øs at all great Debates are ≈øufficiently known to all that ever heard him or had di≈øcour≈øe with him; who for his Loyalty, Courage, and Wi≈ødom (more particularly in the Battel at Edge ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ il, as far as concerned this Noble Lord) had the honour to be ≈øtyled by his late Maje≈øty (when he made him a Peer of England) Praecipuum Coronae no≈øtrae fulcimentum.

Our Letters from Heydelberg intimate, that on Tue≈øday the 13 in≈øtant will be kept a day of Prayers and Thanksgivings in Heydelberg, Wormes, Frankend ‚Ä¢ le, Heylbron, and through all his Electoral Highne≈ø≈øes Dominions of the Palatinate, for the happy Re≈øtauration of His Sacred Maje≈øty of Great Britain. In the great Church of Heydelberg will be a Sermon, who≈øe Text is to be taken out of the ≈øecond Book of Samuel, the 19 Chapter, and the 14 and 15 Ver≈øes, And he bowed the heart of all the men of Judah, even as the heart of one man, ≈øo that they ≈øent this word unto the King, Return thou and all thy ≈øervants. So the King returned, and came to Iordan; and Iudah came to Gilgal to go to meet the King, to conduct the King over Iordan.

Before the Town-hou≈øe therein, there is erected a ≈øtately Fountain adorned with all ≈øorts of Fruits and Flowers, from whence ≈øhall ≈øpring ≈øeverall ≈øorts of Wine, the re≈øt of the day after the Sermon, is to be ≈øpent in Fea≈øting and Jollity, with ≈øounding of Drums and Trumpets, and at night many curious Fire-works are to be performed.

div.head: London.
div.p: On Wedne≈øday the 11 in≈øtant, between one and two in the morning, happened a fire in Thred needle-≈øtreet, between the Exchange and St. Bennet Finck Church, by the Alley commonly called Sweetings rents, ≈øeveral hou≈øes were con≈øumed by it. It is ≈øaid to have been fir≈øt perceived in a wall between the Cock and a Scriveners hou≈øe next adjoyning to it, but in which hou≈øe it began we have no certain information.

div.head: Whitehall.
div.p:
His Maje≈øty in con≈øideration of the eminent loyalty and ≈øignal ≈øervices of that great Warriour and faithful Subject his Excellency the Lord General Monck, hath been graciou≈øly
plea≈øed to confer the≈øe high titles of honor on him.

George Duke of Albemarlie, Earl of Torington, Baron Monck of Potheridge, Beauchamp, and Teyes, Captain General and Commander in chief of all his Maje≈øties Forces in his Kingdomes of England, Scotland, and Ireland, Master of his Maje≈øties hor≈øe, Knight of the most noble Order of the Garter, and one of his Maje≈øties mo≈øt honourable Privy Council.

And as a further addition yet to this mo≈øt Noble per≈øonage, give us leave to tell you of that honour which God him≈øelf hath be≈øtowed on him, in making him the chief In≈øtrument in re≈øtoring his Sacred Maje≈øty, and in his Maje≈øty Peace, plenty and happine≈øs to the three Kingdomes.
On Friday the 13 in≈øtant, his Grace, accompanied by the Duke of Buckingham, and other per≈øonages of high quality, went to take his place in the Hou≈øe of Peers.

In the Army you will find ≈øome alterations of Officers, yet ≈øuch, as that the private ≈øouldiers may rejoyce in having the Nobles to govern them; and the re≈øt of the Officers (who by their con≈øtant adherence to his Excellency, have pre≈øerv'd them≈øelves free from the lea≈øt ≈øu≈øpition, and do ≈øtill continue in command) do now take it for an honour to go a ≈øtep back to make room for ≈øuch noble Chieftains.
Whereof fir≈øt that mo≈øt honourable per≈øonage Aubray Vere Earl of Oxford hath the Regiment that was lately Col. George Smith≈øons, his Capt. Lievtenant is that loyal Knight, Sir William Blake≈øton.
Geo. Smith≈øon late Colonel, is now Major of the ≈øame Regiment.
Tho. Lilburn late Major, now elde≈øt Captain.
Francis Wilkin≈øon Captain.
William Rhoads Captain.
William Wheatley Captain.
Thomas Fairfax formerly Capt. Lievtenant, now Lieutenant to Major Smith≈øon.

For the Regiment of Foot that was lately Col. Fagg's, you have Iohn Vi≈øcount Mordaunt Col. and Sir Tho. Woodcock
Lievt. Col. of the ≈øame Regiment, who were both brought before the ≈øame High Court of Iu≈øtice.
Henry Needler late Lievt. Col. is now made Major of the ≈øame Regiment.
Ier. Harri≈øon late Major, now elde≈øt Captain.
Hartgill Baron Captain.
The Lord Herbert commands now as Colonel that Regiment that was lately Col. Pury's.
And Tho. Pury late Colonel, is now Lievt. Col. of the ≈øame Regiment.
Tho. French late Lievt. Col. now Major.
William Ne≈øt late Major, now elde≈øt Captain.
Major General Sir Edward Ma≈ø≈øey is now Colonel of that Regiment that was lately Colonel Geo. Twi≈øleton's.
Geo. Twi≈øleton late Colonel, now Lievt. Col. of that Regiment.
Sam. Barry late Lievt. Col. now Major.
Dennis Taylor late Major, now elde≈øt Captain.
Iohn Gainsford Captain of that Company late Captain Sowton's.
William Parker Captain.
Ant. Welden Captain.
Tho. Gl ‚Ä¢ d≈øtone Captain of the Company late Captain Thomp≈øons.
William Seymor Captain.
Iohn Bowler Captain of the Company late Captain Shaftoe's.
Be≈øides the≈øe Officers of the Army, there is Major Edward Strange, who (for his faithful ≈øervice to his Maje≈øty, from the beginning to the end of the War) is now made Governour of Hur≈øt Ca≈øtle.

There now ≈øtands committed to the Black-Rod Sir Iohn Thoregood, who had been one of the High Court of Iu≈øtice ‚ñ™ which put to death that Heroick Lord Capel, &c. and endeavoured as much for the brave Earl of Norwich, and Sir Iohn Owen.
Sir William Row of Higham-hills in E≈ø≈øex is al≈øo committed thither.
So is Mr. Samuel Moyer, unknown to no man that hath but heard of Haberda≈øhers Hall, where he filled the Chair and his own pur≈øe.
Mr. George L ‚Ä¢ ngham, a Citizen of London.
Mr. William Wiburn, as good a Citizen as the former.

Colonel Richard Downes, you know who≈øe Iudge he was, and that l ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ r ‚Ä¢ ed, merciful Iudge, M. Richard Keebl ‚Ä¢ , who (for his advantage) in Chancery knew not how to deny any thing, and in a High Court of Iu≈øtice how to grant any thing.

And after all the≈øe, there is one Bowen that belonged to St. Pauls m ‚Ä¢ rk ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ (formerly a Church-yard, till that worldly Saint Alderman Titchbourn turn'd it to a market) who not content to rail at the Bi≈øhops (who one would think have been ≈ølandered long enough) broke out into ≈øuch impudent language again≈øt the Hou≈øe of Peers now ≈øitting, as a man would ≈øcarce have thrown at the other Hou≈øe, for which and other enormities he is now honored with an impri≈øonment, though Bowen to ‚Ä¢ d the Wi ‚Ä¢ ne≈ø≈øe, that for all this he hoped to ≈øee another Turn, but what he means by another Turn, a little time will ≈øhew.

Be≈øides the≈øe mentioned under the Black-Rod, there are three more ≈øent lately to the Tower, particularly Col. Hacker, who carried a Partizan and commanded the Guards when our late Soveraign was put to death, where this Colonel was on the Scaffo ‚Ä¢ d, but on Thur≈øday la≈øt was for High-Trea≈øon committed to the Tower.

And ye≈øterday July 12. Colonel Axtell was ≈øent thither, who commanded the Iri≈øh Foot for the Committee of Safety, and is the mo≈øt injur'd per≈øon alive if he have not kill'd forty times more in cold blood then in hot; but how he got the Lord Montgarrets E≈øtate, or how that Noble Lord came to lo≈øe it, we need not tell you.

And (after all) the ≈øame day was committed M. Thomas Scot (not long ≈øince c ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ l'd Secretary Scot) who was ≈øent pri≈øoner out of Flanders, being one of the ≈øeven excepted from pardon, a per≈øon (in the opinion of the people of England) not to be match'd in Scotland, nor any where el≈øe but where he now is: And (fo ‚Ä¢ the ≈øatisfaction of all good men) both Scotland and Ireland, as the Letters thence a≈ø≈øure us, are as quite as England, and (maugre all little inventions) are like ≈øo to continue‚ñ™
One part of this City called Galata, is lately con≈øumed by fire, except only the Covent and Church of the Je≈øuits.
Here is dreadfull news come from the I≈øle of Cephalonia, where by an Earth-quake two Territories called Argu≈øtoly and Paloty were de≈øtroyed, and above 2000 Inhabitants mi≈øerably peri≈øhed.

div.head: From Ca≈øhaw, June 18, and 20.
div.p:
The Corps of the decea≈øed Prince Ragotzkie was carried to Oet≈øchr the 18. of this in≈øtant, to which place the Prince≈øs his mother (with the Court) removed, expecting the coming of an Amba≈ø≈øador from Vienna. This Prince≈øs ≈øubmits her ≈øelf, with the re≈øidue of the Army, ammunition and provi≈øion, to the Devotion of his Imperial Maje≈øty. And in regard the Grand Seignior threatens to keep the two Juri≈ødictions, pretending to have won them by the Sword, and will not allow they ≈øhould do homage to the Emperour, or if they do, hee will utterly de≈øtroy them with Fire and Sword, (in pur≈øuance whereof hee hath commanded thither a con≈øiderable Force) of which adverti≈øement being given to
ours, the Prince Palatine, Gen. Su≈øa, and the Pre≈øident of the Chamber of Hungary, are with all ≈øpeed gone from Experies, Gen. Hey≈øter with his forces being advanced before them, and continuing their march dayly by break of day, that they may put a Garri≈øon into tho≈øe two Juri≈ødictions before the Turks arrive. The Ca≈øtavian Vice-General Pethoe Sigmund is likewi≈øe marched thither from Tockhay the 18 in≈øtant with 700 Hu≈ø≈øars, but ours arrived the ≈øame day at Tockhay. The Palatine is in good health, Gen. Su≈øa was ≈øomewhat ill-di≈øpo≈øed, but is now fully recovered. The news of the taking of Waradin doth not continue, notwith≈øtanding it ≈øtill remaineth be≈øieged. Sackmar is taken, and ≈øtrengthned by Barckay with 2000 Turks.

The Mo≈øcovites are totally routed about Grodno by the Poli≈øh General Czarneckie, there being kill'd about 7 or 8000 men. The Mo≈øcovites Field-Mar≈øhal Chowatzkie is begirt with the Poles about Lockwitz; his party u≈øeth all endeavours to relieve him, but will hardly effect any thing. The Tartars and Co≈ø≈øacks make a fearfull havock in Mo≈øcovie and White-Ru≈ø≈øia; ≈øo ≈øoon as th ‚Ä¢
„Äà‚óä„Äâ forces come neerer tho≈øe places, they „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ to put them≈øelves under the Poles „Äà‚óä„Äâ
Bi≈øchaw, a ≈øtrong Fort, is by a „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
by the Poles, the King him≈øelf goeth to the Camp with all his Nobles. Here is a report, as if the Lithuanian Armie ≈øhould have taken the Town of Welda, but not the Ca≈øtle.

The Mo≈øcovites con≈øi≈øting of 22000 men advanced betwixt Slonnin and Miszow, where they were met by the Poli≈øh Generals Sapicha and Cznarneckie, the Mo≈øcovites endeavouring to take their pa≈ø≈øage over a ditch, were attaqued with ≈øo good ≈øucce≈øs on the Poli≈øh ≈øide, that they were pre≈øently brought into di≈øorder, their whole Infantry con≈øi≈øting of above 8000 men being defeated, and their Hor≈øe, which is thought to amount to the number of 16000. being forced to retreat to the woods. The Poles have taken 40 pieces of Ordnance, 100 Colours, with all the baggage and part of the ammunition, the Mo≈øcovian Gen. Chowanzky having put fire to the re≈øt of the powder, and him≈øelf taking his flight ≈øhamefully for Vilna. It is thought he will fall into the hands of Obosky, who cometh with an Army out of Samogitia. The Poli≈øh Gen. Czarnecky (after ≈øo great a Victory is now gone for Lockewiz, which is ≈øtill be≈øieged by 2000 Mo≈øcovites, who≈øe qu ‚Ä¢ rters he intends to beat up. From Tran≈øilvania it is certified, that Prince Ragotzky was ≈ølain in the battel with the Turks, who≈øe mother hath delivered to the Emperour the Hungarian Counties with the ≈øumm of 100000 Rixdollers, upon which the Turks are retreated.

The Elector of Brandenburgh is expected here within very few daies, it being reported that he is cho≈øen for a Mediator betwixt the King of Poland, and the grand Duke of Mo≈øcovy, who ≈øeems to be inclinable to that accommodation, though the contrary may be judged by his great preparations, being re≈øolved to enter Lithuania at the head of 20000 men: This hath cau≈øed the Nobility of Poland, who ≈øeemed to be ready to fall into divi≈øion among them≈øelves, to unite again more ≈øtrictly then ever again≈øt the Mo≈øcovites, and to ingage to his Poli≈øh Maje≈øty to afford him either men to ≈øtrengthen his Army, or money to ≈øupport it.

The Swedi≈øh men of War formerly detained by Vice-Admiral Ruyter, under the command of the Canon of Copenhaghen, and relea≈øed ≈øince the ≈øub≈øcribing of the Treaty, are now in this harbour, where they are to remain until all the Swedi≈øh forces be drawn out of Zealand‚ñ™ In the mean time the Swedes are bu≈øie them≈øelves about the demoli≈øhing of the fortifications of Cronenburgh, and are tran≈øporting off all the Pali≈ø≈øado ‚Ä¢ s into the Province of Schonen.

The Imperial and Brandenburgi≈øh forces do keep ≈øtill the places they had taken in Pomerania and Meckleburgh, but we hear that for certain the fir≈øt have received order to remove by the ‚Ä¢ 8 in≈øtant, and to march into Bohemia. In the mean while the Swedes are making ≈øome preparations here and at Stralzund, it being reported that their de≈øign is to bring the City of Bremen wholly under their obedience‚ñ™ The men of War they do keep before Warnemunde, having taken a ≈øhip going to Copenhaghen, in which were three Deputies of the City of Bo≈øtock, whom they keep pri≈øoners.

The Elector of Brandenburgh is to go from hence this week, for Koningsbergh in Pru≈ø≈øia, to mediate a Peace between Poland and the grand Duke of Mo≈øcovy, being re≈øolved, In ca≈øe the la≈øt do refu≈øe ≈øuch rea≈øonable Propo≈øitions as ≈øhall be offered unto him, to joyn his forces to the Poli≈øh Army again≈øt him.

The 26 of the la≈øt moneth, M. Coyet, Extraordinary Envoy of Swedeland, made a vi≈øit to the Amba≈ø≈øadors of Denmark, who returned the ≈øame civility the next day after. The ≈øame day M. Herbert, one of the Deputies of the States General to his Dani≈øh Maje≈øty, arrived here; M. Beverweert is gone for England, and is to be very ≈øpeedily followed by the other Amba≈ø≈øadors, who are ≈øent to congratulate the King of England, in the name of the States, who ≈øeem to be willing to ≈øend likewi≈øe ≈øome Commi≈ø≈øioners to Mun≈øter, to end the difference between that City and their Bi≈øhop. The Royal Prince≈øs, and the Prince of Orange her ≈øon, are yet at Harlem, where they have been ≈øumptuou≈øly treated by the Magi≈øtrate.

The Bi≈øhops of Uzez, Viviers, and Ni≈ømes, have each of them ≈øet out two hundred men, to ha≈øten the demoli≈øhing of the fortifications of Orange, for fear of a contrary order, they being very earne≈øt to have the Prote≈øtants deprived of that place of refuge. The number of the workmen that are imployed about the Cittadel of Mar≈øeille hath been likewi≈øe doubled, and the ≈øame is ≈øo forwards, that ≈øome pieces of Ordnance are already mounted upon the Bullworks, The Edicts formerly ≈øpoken of to have been pa≈ø≈øed for this Province, were about the Soap, whereby that which doth co≈øt now five Livers, would have co≈øt twenty five, and that called of the Franc Salle, concerning
the Gabell of the Salt, the rarley whereof had been given to the Cardinal Mazarin's Secretary, with power to demand the arrears of it as far as twenty years back, which would have produced a very va≈øt ≈øum of money. As to the bu≈øine≈øs of the Domaine, the Originals of the Grants made by the Counts of Provence having been demanded by the Court, only tho≈øe excepted that were made to the Officers of the Soveraign Courts, and to the per≈øons of Quality, the fir≈øt Pre≈øident would not carry them to the Chamber, to avoid the rumour, but cau≈øed them to be ≈øigned by two of his Confidents, and adding thereunto the names of ≈øuch of the Councellors as he thought to be his friends, he cau≈øed them to be regi≈øtred, but he hath been ≈øince di≈øowned by the Councellors, and the Greffice declared that he was compelled by force to regi≈øter them.

Chevalier de Tre≈ølon, Amba≈ø≈øador for the King in the North, hath ≈øent M. Blerman his Secretary with the Articles of the Treaty between Swedeland and Denmark, to be ≈øub≈øcribed by his Maje≈øty. Made moi≈øelle coming from Court hath ≈øtaid a while at Champigny. The Abbot of Richelieu hath complained to the A≈ø≈øembly of the Clergy again≈øt the Bi≈øhop of Autun, for in≈øerting in his new hi≈øtory of the Cardinals, ≈øomething prejudicial to the reputation of his Unkle the late Cardinal de Richelieu, in the bu≈øine≈øs of M. de Marillac, and of the late Queen Mother his Benefactrix. The ≈øaid Bi≈øhop to prevent the de≈øire of the A≈ø≈øembly for taking tho≈øe pieces out of his book, offered to do it of him≈øelf, ≈øaying it was a ≈øtone he had found in his way which he threw at his enemies head, but withall de≈øired the A≈ø≈øembly to give liberty to the Hi≈øtorians to write the truth. We have news here that the Court is to be at Fontainebleau the 16 in≈øtant, and intends to come hither by the 25. Great ha≈øt is making to prepare all at the Louver. Few daies after the Court is to remove to Compiegn, from whence the Cardinal Mazarin will go to la Fere with
the Count de Fuen≈øaldagne, there to end the difference between Savoy and Mantua.

div.head: ADVERTISEMENTS.
div.p:
There is a fair and plea≈øant hou≈øe in Acton in the County of Middle≈øex, ≈øet about with Elm trees, with Gardens, Orchards, and all ≈øorts of plea≈øant fruits, it contains twenty fair rooms compleatly furni≈øhed, and water to every Office, Coach hou≈øe Barn Stable, and a Clo≈øe to keep hor≈øes in, to be let f ‚Ä¢ r t ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢ m of y ‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ (the bedding and hou≈øhold-stuff to be ≈øold) Enquire at the Golden „Äà‚óä„Äâ in Thred needle-≈øtreet, or of G ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ man
‚Ä¢ ib ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , who lives over again≈øt the ≈ø ‚Ä¢ id Mo ‚Ä¢ ≈øe in Acton, and you may be further informed.

Lo≈øt on Tue≈øday night July 10. 16 ‚Ä¢ 0. at the Swan at Hockly, a bald face, brown bay h ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øe, ‚Ä¢ b ‚Ä¢ ut fourteen handful high, trots and gallops, paces a little, If any one can give notice hereof unto Mr. George Tru ‚Ä¢ ≈øhaw, at the Pinder of Wakefield „Äà‚óä„Äâ Gra ‚Ä¢ es-Inne-lane, or unto Mr. Richard Gilpin at the Swan in Hockly, they ≈øhall have twent, ≈øhillings for their pains.

A „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
‚Ä¢ awney bound, with a white bre≈øt, a bald face, a cut tail, and a ≈øcar on his farther leg behind, was lo≈øt o ‚Ä¢ Munday la≈øt the 9th day of July; if any one can bring him to Mr. Looder a Taylor, at his hou≈øe in the Black-Friers neer the old Play-hou≈øe, or to Mr. G ‚Ä¢ eens a Cook at the Queens Arms in Holborn, he ≈øhall be well rewarded for his pains.

I ‚Ä¢ any one hath hou≈øes in London or the Suburbs, to the value of 100 150. or 200 l. per annum, or a Colledge Leafe of the value of 100. or
‚Ä¢ 00 l. per annum, in the Counties of Bucks, Bedford, Hamp≈øhire, or Wilts, good title, which he would put to ≈øale, if he repair to Mr. Samuel Mearne, his Ma ‚Ä¢ e≈øties Book-binder in Little-Britain, he ≈øhall be informed of one that will deal with him for ≈øuch a purcha≈øe.

Whereas in ≈øome p ‚Ä¢ ints there is mention made of the manner of the reception of Mon≈øieur Pelnitz, was particularized that he was conducted to audience in his Maje≈øties own Coach; we mu≈øt inform the Reader, that it was not his Maje≈øties Coach, but the Coach of the Earl of Manche≈øter, Lord Chamberlain of his Majesties hou≈øhold.

div.head: Adverti≈øements of Books.
div.p:
Newly reprinted, with very large and profitable additions, Via recta ad vitam longam; A Treati≈øe wherein the right way and be≈øt manner of living for attaining to a long and healthful life, is clearly demon≈øtrated, and punctua ‚Ä¢ ly applied to every age and con≈øtitution of body; by Tob. Venn ‚Ä¢ r, Doctor of Phy≈øick in Bathe; with a very nece≈ø≈øary and compendious Treati≈øe of the famous ‚Ä¢ ath ‚Ä¢

Sold by J. Siens, at the Gro≈øs-keys in St. Pauls Church-yard.

Hi≈øtorians, Grammarians, Orators, and P ‚Ä¢ ets. By Edward La ‚Ä¢ kin ‚ñ™ Sold by Henry Ev ‚Ä¢ ≈øden as the Grey-bound in St. Pauls Church-yard. The price 2 s. 64.

Cromwell's bloody ≈ølaughter-hou≈øe; or his damnable de≈øigns laid and practi≈øed by him and his Negro's, in contriving the murther of his ≈øacred Maje≈øty King Charles the fir≈øt, di≈øcovered by a per≈øon of honor. Sold by H. Ever≈øden at the Grey-hound in St. Pauls Church-yard. The price is 12 d.

Davids Deliverance and Thank≈øgiving: A Sermon preach't before his Maje≈øty at Whitehall on the day of Thank≈øgiving, June 28. 1660. by G. Shel ‚Ä¢ on, D. D. and Dean of his Maje≈øties Chappel Royal. A Black ‚Ä¢ mith, and no Je≈øuite: or a true relation how‚ñ™ I William Houlbrook Black-≈ømith of Marlborough was betrayed by Cornet George Ioyce, who carried the King pri≈øoner from Hol ‚Ä¢ by‚ñ™ and of the unju≈øt in pri≈øoning of me, and my ≈øeveral examinations before Brad≈øhaw, and his bloody crew, with my an≈øwers unto all of them, as you may read in the following di≈øcour≈øe. Written in the time of my impri≈øonment and now put to publick view. Sold by Francis L ‚Ä¢ ≈øh, next door to the Pauls-head Tavern at Pauls-Chain.

div.head: London.
div.p:
On Wedne≈øday the 11 in≈øtant, between one and two in the morning, happened a fire in Thred-needle-≈øtreet, between
the Exchange and St. Bennet Finck Church, by the Alley commonly called Sweetings rents, ≈øeveral hou≈øes were con≈øumed by it. It is ≈øaid to have been fir≈øt perceived in a wall between the Cock and a Scriveners hou≈øe next adjoyning to it, but in which hou≈øe it began we have no certain information.

div.head: Whitehall.
div.p: His Maje≈øty in con≈øideration of the eminent loyalty and ≈øignal ≈øervices of that great Warriour and faithful Subject his Excellency the Lord General Monck, hath been graciou≈øly plea≈øed to confer the≈øe high titles of honor on him.

George Duke of Albemarlie, Earl of Torington, Baron Monck of Potheridge, Beauchamp, and Teyes, Captain General and Commander in chief of all his Maje≈øties Forces in his Kingdomes of England, Scotland, and Ireland, Master of his Maje≈øties hor≈øe, Knight of the most noble Order of the Garter, and one of his Maje≈øties mo≈øt honourable Privy Council.

And as a further addition yet to this mo≈øt Noble per≈øonage, give us leave to tell you of that honour which God him≈øelf hath be≈øtowed on him, in making him the chief In≈øtrument in re≈øtoring his Sacred Maje≈øty, and in his Maje≈øty Peace, plenty and happine≈øs to the three Kingdomes.
On Friday the 13 in≈øtant, his Gr ‚Ä¢ ce, accompanied by the Duke of Buckingham, and other per≈øonages of high quality, went to take his place in the Hou≈øe of Peers.

In the Army you will find ≈øome alterations of Officers, yet ≈øuch, as that the private ≈øouldiers may rejoyce in having the Nobles to govern them; and the re≈øt of the Officers (who by their con≈øtant adherence to his Excellency, have pre≈øerv'd them≈øelves free from the lea≈øt ≈øu≈øpition, and do ≈øtill continue in command) do now take it for an honour to go a ≈øtep back to make room for ≈øuch noble Chieftains.

Whereof fir≈øt that mo≈øt honourable per≈øonage Aubray Vere Earl of Oxford hath the Regiment that was lately Col. George Smith≈øons, his Capt. Lievtenant is that loyal Knight, Sir William Blake≈øton; Geo. Smith≈øon late Colonel,
is now Major of the ≈øame Regiment; Tho. Lilburn late Major, now elde≈øt Captain; Fran. Wilkin≈øon Captain, William Rhoads Captain, William Wheatley Captain, Thomas Fairfax formerly Capt. Lievtenant, now Lievtenant to Major Smith≈øon.

For the Regiment of Foot that was lately Col. Fagg's, you have Iohn Vi≈øcount Mordaunt Col. and Sir Tho. Woodcock Lievt. Col. of the ≈øame Regiment, who were both brought before the ≈øame High Court of Iu≈øtice; Henry Needler late Lievt. Col. is now made Major of the ≈øame Regiment; Ier. Harri≈øon late „Äà‚óä„Äâ , now elde≈øt Captain, Hartgill Baron Captain.

The Lord Herbert commands now as Colonel that Regiment that was lately Col. Pury's, and Tho. Pury late Colonel, is now Lievt. Col. of the ≈øame Regiment, Tho. French late Lievt. Col. now Major, William Ne≈øt late Major, now elde≈øt Captain.

Major General Sir Edward Ma≈ø≈øey is now Colonel of that Regiment that was lately Colonel Geo. Twi≈øleton's, Geo. Twi≈øleton late Colonel, now Lievt. Col. of that Regiment, Sam. Barry late Lievt. Col. now Major, Dennis Taylor late Major, now elde≈øt Captain, Iohn Gains≈øord Captain of that Company late Captain Sowton's, William Parker Captain, Ant. Welden Captain, Tho. Gl ‚Ä¢ d≈øtone Captain of the Company late Captain Thomp≈øons, William Seymor Captain, Iohn Bowler Captain of the Company late Captain Shaftoe's.
Be≈øides the≈øe Officers of the Army, there is Major Edward Strange, who (for his faithful ≈øervice to his Maje≈øty, from the beginning to the end of the War) is now made Governour of Hur≈øt Ca≈øtle.

There now ≈øtands committed to the Black-Rod Sir Iohn Thor ‚Ä¢ good, who had been one of the High Court of Iu≈øtice, which put to death that Heroick Lord Capel, &c. and endeavoured as much for the brave Earl of Norwich, and Sir Iohn Owen.
Sir William Row of Higham-hills in E≈ø≈øex is al≈øo committed thither.
So is Mr. Samuel Mayer, unknown to no man that hath but hear ‚Ä¢ of Haberda≈øhers Hall, where he filled the Chair and his own pur≈øe.
Mr. George Langham, a Citizen of London.
Mr. William Wiburn, as good a Citizen as the former.

Colonel Richard Downes, you know who≈øe Iudge he was, and that learned, merciful Iudge, Mr. Richard Keeble, who (for his advantage) in Chancery knew not how to deny any thing, and in a High Court of Iu≈øtice how to grant ‚Ä¢ ny thing.

And after all the≈øe, there is one Bowen that belonged to St. Pauls market (formerly a Church-yard, till that worldly Saint Alderman Titchbourn turn'd it to a marker) who not content to rail at the Bi≈øhops (who one would think have been ≈ølandered long enough) broke out into ≈øuch impudent language again≈øt the Hou≈øe of Peers now ≈øitting, as a man would ≈øcarce have thrown at the other Hou≈øe, for which and other enormities he is now honored with an impri≈øonment, though Bowen told the Witne≈ø≈øe, that for ‚Ä¢ ll this he hoped to ≈øee another Turn, but what he means by another Turn, a little time will ≈øhew.

Be≈øides the≈øe mentioned under the Black-Rod, there are three more ≈øent lately to the Tower, particularly Col. Hacker, who carried a Patrizan and commanded the Guards when o ‚Ä¢ r late Soveraign was put to death, where this Colonel was on the Scaffo ‚Ä¢ d, but on Thur≈øday la≈øt was for High-Trea≈øon committed to the Tower.

And ye≈øterday July 12. Colonel Axtell was ≈øent thither, who commanded the Iri≈øh Foot for the Committee of Safety, and is the mo≈øt injur'd per≈øon alive if he have not kill'd forty times more in cold blood then in hot; but how he got the Lord Montgarrets E≈øtate, or how that Noble Lord came to lo≈øe it, we need not tell you.

And (after all) the ≈øame day was committed M. Thomas Scot (not long ≈øince call'd Secretary Scot) who was ≈øent pri≈øoner out of Flanders, being one of the ≈øeven excepted from pardon, a per≈øon (in the opinion of the people of England) not to be march'd in Scotland, nor any where el≈øe but where he now is: And (for the ≈øatisfaction of all good men) both Scotland and Ireland, as the Letters thence a≈ø≈øure us, are as quiet as England, and (maugre all little inventions) are like ≈øo to continue.
London, Printed by John Macock, and Tho. Newcombe, 1660.
